title: Danielle M. Barnas
text:
I am an early career field researcher and data analyst in my final year as an MS candidate in the Biology Department at CSU Northridge. Current research focuses on the impact of natural environmental gradients (i.e. submarine groundwater discharge, SGD) on coastal coral reef biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. I aim to assess the relationship of species and functional trait diversity along an SGD gradient of two coral reefs in Mo’orea, French Polynesia, as well as understand the physiological effects of SGD on multiple benthic taxa and assemblages of varying species and functional identities in high and low SGD influence.
Previous work has focused on marine ecological shifts in response to climate change and restoration techniques of coral reef ecosystems. After receiving my BA in Marine Science from the University of San Diego in 2015, I spent three years in the Florida Keys working with local environmental organizations (i.e. Coral Restoration Foundation, Mote Marine Laboratory, and Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission). In these positions I helped monitor and restore threatened or damaged reefs, as well as study effects of climate change on those ecosystems. I began working at CSUN in 2018 as a Research Technician in Dr. Nyssa Silbiger’s Quantitative Ecology lab before being accepted as a graduate student into her lab in 2021.
As a technician and graduate student, I have worked primarily in R to develop protocols, training materials, and data processing scripts for lab equipment, a new mesocosm system, and standard procedures. I have also created an R package for cleaning, processing, and analyzing data from in situ environmental parameter loggers and other lab and field data collections, all still used by current lab members. I have worked in R Shiny to simplify processing and visualization of data from multiple Onset HOBO loggers (Conductivity-Temperature, pH, and Water Level). I am currently enrolled in a professional data analytics certification program, where I am gaining experience in SQL and Tableau to assist in my pursuit of ecological and environmental data analytics.

title: R Shiny Apps
text:
(created 5/01/2022)


Applicable Onset HOBO loggers:
- Conductivity-Temperature (U24-002-C)
- Water Level (U20-001-02)
- pH (MX2501)
How to use this app:
1. Select a logger type and raw csv to import
2. Input calibration information: date, time, values
3. Input launch and retrieval information: date, time
Tables with calibrated data and figures showing the time series between launch and retrieval dates will autopopulate. A CSV file of the calibrated and cut data can be downloaded using the bottom button.

title: R Packages
text:
R package to clean, organize, and analyze data from Onset HOBO in situ data loggers. Functions have been created for:
- HOBO U24-002-C Conductivity-Temperature
- HOBO MX2501 pH
- HOBO U20 Water Level
In-development repository can be found HERE
Available functions:

CT_cleanup

Import, clean up, and export multiple raw conductivity-temperature (CT) data files from the HOBO CT Logger.


CT_one_cal

Calibration with a single set of reference values.

Calculate temperature-compensated Specific Conductance and one-point calibration for CT logger data. This function reads in a dataframe containing electrical conductivity logs from a conductivity-temperature logger and calculates specific conductance from in situ electrical conductivity and temperature readings.


CT_two_cal

Calibration with two sets of reference values.

Calculate temperature-compensated Specific Conductance from a two-point calibration (single high reference and single low reference) for CT logger data. This function reads in a dataframe containing electrical conductivity logs from a conductivity-temperature logger and calculates specific conductance from in situ electrical conductivity and temperature readings.


WL_cleanup

Import, clean up, and export multiple raw water level (depth) data files from the HOBO Water Level Logger.


pH_cleanup

Import, clean up, and export multiple raw pH data files from the HOBO pH Logger.

title: Research Interests
section: Additonal projects (Assisted as a research technician at CSUN)
text:
Additonal projects (Assisted as a research technician at CSUN)

Becker, D.M. and Silbiger, N.J. 2020. Nutrient and sediment loading affect multiple facets of functionality in a tropical branching coral. Journal of Experimental Biology 223.


Fields, J.B. and Silbiger, N.J. 2022. Foundation species loss alters multiple ecosystem functions within temperate tidepool communities. Marine Science Progress Series 683.


Kerlin, J.R., Barnas, D.M.*, Silbiger, N.J. In Progress (anticiipated 2023). Effects of submarine groundwater discharge and coral-coral interactions on common coral species, Porites rus.


Chiachi, A., Barnas, D.M.*, Silbiger, N.J. In Progress (anticiipated 2023). Determining the effects of marine heatwaves on red abalone, Haliotis rufescens, across multiple size classes.

title: Research Interests
text:
Other reserach interests

Coral reef conservation and restoration

Temporal changes of marine ecosystems due to disturbance events or climage change

Functional traits as key drivers of BEF relationships

Climate change impacts to organismal and community physiology

Impacts of natural processes (i.e. submarine groundwater discharge) on organismal and community physiology
